item.title: [Itrfoundation] Gratitude for the Forgotten Mayflower Compact
item.description:
In November 1620, after arriving in Cape Cod, the Pilgrims signed the Mayflower Compact before setting foot on land. Though often overlooked today, the Compact remains a foundational document in the development of American constitutionalism and self-government. Constitutional scholar James McClellan wrote that by adopting the Compact, the Pilgrims brought a contractual theory of government to the New World—an idea that would later influence colonial charters, state constitutions, and even the U.S. Constitution itself.
This Thanksgiving, remembering the Mayflower Compact highlights the deep historical roots of American freedom and why these early commitments to self-rule remain a blessing worth celebrating.

The post Gratitude for the Forgotten Mayflower Compact appeared first on ITR Foundation.

item.title: [Itrfoundation] The Fight Over America’s Institutions is a Test of Our Republic
item.description:
A prediction of Supreme Court expansion sparks a deeper debate about whether sweeping institutional reforms align with or undermine the constitutional framework the Founders designed.
America was built as a republic, not a pure democracy, with federalism, separation of powers, the Electoral College, and an independent judiciary intentionally structured to restrain majority impulses and protect liberty.
Modern proposals to reshape long-standing institutions, from court packing to weakening states’ authority, reflect frustration with constitutional guardrails, but those guardrails are essential to preserving the republic “if we can keep it.”

The post The Fight Over America’s Institutions is a Test of Our Republic appeared first on ITR Foundation.

item.description:

item.title: [Itrfoundation] “We Need to Put the Taxpayer In Control”
item.description:
Central Iowa taxpayers and legislators voiced overwhelming frustration with high property taxes, citing rising local spending and a lack of transparency. Audience testimony highlighted widespread concern about school spending priorities and commercial property burdens, with many noting that facilities expansion has outpaced academic results and that high property taxes are discouraging business investment. Participants agreed that meaningful property tax relief must address the root cause—local spending growth—and put taxpayers back at the center of the system, not simply tweak levy rates or formulas.

The post “We Need to Put the Taxpayer In Control” appeared first on ITR Foundation.

item.description:

And for an age group least likely to become ill with COVID-19. The coronavirus had a significant impact on local school district finances and they seemed to survive...

item.title: [Californiapolicycenter] Politically Viable Water Supply Projects
item.description:
A few years ago I was involved in an effort to qualify a ballot initiative, the “Water Infrastructure Funding Act.” While we failed to gather sufficient signatures to get it onto the November 2022 state ballot, if it had been approved by voters, water scarcity in California would have been eliminated forever. item.title: [Californiapolicycenter] EVs and California’s Future Demand for Electricity
item.description:

And when it comes to electrification, few categories of consumption are likely to outweigh the demands of EVs. With a focus on...

item.title: [Johnlocke] Democrats don’t see Britain’s cautionary tale
item.description:
John Daniel Davidson writes for the Federalist about lessons to be learned from Britain’s political decline. It’s easy to look at a collapsing civil society in a foreign country and comfort ourselves that, despite all our problems, we’re not as bad off as those people. item.title: [Johnlocke] Government watchdog exposes Obamacare subsidy scam
item.description:
Victor Nava writes for the New York Post about the recent exposure of Obamacare subsidies’ flaws. item.title: [Jbartlett] A ‘Repeal Day’ glance at Liquor Commission revenues
item.description:
December 5 is neither a federal nor state day of celebration, but it probably should be. That evening, […]

item.title: [Beacontn] Small Cost, Big Returns: Technical Schools Building Tennessee
item.description: Technical schools may not be the right choice for every high school graduate. item.title: [Idahofreedom] Week in Review: The Invasion of Idaho
item.description: The United States of America is in a crisis.
